questions.question:
Question 1: A veterinarian with fever, chills, and myalgia is diagnosed with Q fever. Which of the 
following is the most common reservoir of this disease?
questions.explanation:
Ticks are the most common reservoir of Q fever. Coxiella burnetii is the causative pathogen. The most commonly identified sources of human 
infection are farm animals, such as cattle, goats, and sheep. Infected mammals shed C. burnetii in their urine, feces, milk, and placenta. Human exposure 
to C. burnetii may occur as a result of inhalation of contaminated aerosols arising from the 
placenta or parturient fluids of infected livestock or from contaminated secretions on the surface 
of newborn animals. People working with farm animals and veterinarians are at a higher risk of infection.
questions.chapter_heading: Medical Entomology - Ticks  Fleas and Mites

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is not transmitted by hard ticks?
questions.explanation: Relapsing fever is not transmitted by hard ticks, but by soft ticks.
questions.chapter_heading: Medical Entomology - Ticks  Fleas and Mites

questions.question:
Question 3: Peripheral smear of a patient with high grade fever, arthralgia, and myalgia is given below. 
Which of the following transmits this disease? 638 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with peripheral smear showing maltese cross appearance is suggestive 
of babesiosis. It is transmitted by ticks. 647 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Medical Entomology - Ticks  Fleas and Mites

questions.question:
Question 4: A patient with fever and joint pain presented with the following lesion on his left leg. Which 
of the following transmits this disease?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing bulls eye rash is suggestive of Lyme 
disease. It is transmitted by Ixodes tick.
questions.chapter_heading: Medical Entomology - Ticks  Fleas and Mites

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is not true about the vector in the given image?
questions.explanation:
The given image is of a soft tick. It can withstand starvation for over a year. The head of the soft tick lies ventrally and it does not have a scutum. It serves as a reservoir for Q 
fever and transmits relapsing fever.
questions.chapter_heading: Medical Entomology - Ticks  Fleas and Mites

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following is false about the vector in the given image? 640 
Sold by @itachibot

options.c: Its nymphal stage has seven stages
options.d: It lays hundreds of eggs at once

questions.explanation:
The given image is of a hard tick. The hard tick has only one nymphal stage. It has a hard chitinous shield called the scutum which covers the entire back in males a small 
portion in the front in females. It feeds night and day and cannot withstand starvation. It lays 
several hundreds or thousands of eggs in one sitting.
questions.chapter_heading: Medical Entomology - Ticks  Fleas and Mites

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following are also known as chiggers?
questions.explanation:
Larval forms of trombiculid mites are also known as chiggers. They are spider-like arthropods which are vectors for scrub typhus. The image given below shows 
trombiculid mite. 648 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Medical Entomology - Ticks  Fleas and Mites

questions.question:
Question 8: Which of the following diseases is transmitted by the vector shown in the image given below? 641 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image is of a reduviid bug. It transmits American trypanosomiasis, also known 
as Chagas disease. Reduviid bug is also known as the kissing bug or triatomine bug. It lives in cracks, fissures and 
other spaces in the walls and ceilings of human dwellings. Residual spraying with HCH or dieldrin 
is used for the control of these bugs. Option B: African trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness) is transmitted by the tsetse fly. Option C: Onchocerciasis is transmitted by the blackfly (Simulium). Option D: Visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar) is transmitted by the sandfly.
questions.chapter_heading: Medical Entomology - Ticks  Fleas and Mites

questions.question:
Question 9: A 10-year-old boy presents with complaints of nocturnal pruritus. Examination shows 
burrows over the skin of his hands. KOH mount prepared from these lesions is given below. 
Which of the following vectors transmits this disease?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and KOH mount showing the itch mite are suggestive of scabies. It is 
transmitted by itch mite or Sarcoptes scabiei. The female parasite burrows into the epidermis where it breeds. It is a small parasite, barely 
visible to the naked eye, with 4 pairs of legs. Its life cycle consists of four stagesâ€”egg, larva, nymph, and adult stages. Its spread can be 
through close contact or contaminated clothes. Benzyl benzoate is very effective as a sarcopticide. HCH, tetmosol, and sulphur ointments are also 
used. The image given below shows itch mite. 649 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Medical Entomology - Ticks  Fleas and Mites

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by mites?
questions.explanation:
Kyasanur forest disease is not transmitted by mites. It is a viral hemorrhagic fever transmitted by 
hard ticks. Scabies, scrub typhus, and rickettsial pox are transmitted by mites.
questions.chapter_heading: Medical Entomology - Ticks  Fleas and Mites

questions.question:
Question 11: You are given the following slide during your community medicine practicals. Which of the 
following diseases is not transmitted by this vector?
questions.explanation:
The above image is of a head louse. It does not transmit endemic typhus which is transmitted by 
fleas. Lice transmit epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, and trench fever.
questions.chapter_heading: Medical Entomology - Ticks  Fleas and Mites

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following diseases is transmitted by lice?
questions.explanation:
Epidemic typhus is transmitted by lice and caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. Murine typhus is transmitted by the rat flea. Tick typhus is transmitted by a hard tick. Scrub 
typhus is transmitted by trombiculid mite.
questions.chapter_heading: Medical Entomology - Ticks  Fleas and Mites

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is not transmitted by lice?
questions.explanation:
Q fever is not transmitted by lice. It is spread by the inhalation of contaminated aerosols 
containing Coxiella burnetti. Soft ticks are the most common reservoirs of Q fever. The aerosols arise from the placenta or 
parturient fluids of infected livestock or from contaminated secretions on the surface of newborn 
animals.
questions.chapter_heading: Medical Entomology - Ticks  Fleas and Mites

questions.question: Question 14: Identify the following vector which transmits murine typhus.
questions.explanation: The given image is of a rat flea-Xenopsylla cheopis. It transmits murine typhus.
questions.chapter_heading: Medical Entomology - Ticks  Fleas and Mites

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by rat fleas?
questions.explanation:
Pneumonic plague is not transmitted by rat fleas. It is transmitted by inhalation of aerosolized 
droplets. Rat fleas are vectors for murine or endemic typhus, bubonic plague, and hymenolepiasis caused 
by Hymenolepis nana and Hymenolepis diminuta. 650 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Medical Entomology - Ticks  Fleas and Mites

questions.question:
Question 16: A flea survey is being conducted in an area prone to outbreaks of plague. Which of the 
following indices is not used for this purpose?
questions.explanation:
Incidence of plague is not an index used in flea surveys. Flea indices that are used in flea surveys 
are: â€¢ General flea index â€¢ Specific flea index â€¢ Percentage incidence of flea species â€¢ Rodent infestation rate
questions.chapter_heading: Medical Entomology - Ticks  Fleas and Mites

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following is true about sand fleas?
questions.explanation:
Sand fleas cause ulcers in the feet. They are also called jigger or chigoe fleas. The species called Tunga penetrans is of particular 
importance as it causes tungiasis. The fertilized female burrows into the skin of the feet, often beneath the nail and causes ulcers. 
Tetanus and gas gangrene frequently occur because of secondary infection. They flourish best in sandy soil and are found in the western parts of India. The below image shows a sand flea.
questions.chapter_heading: Medical Entomology - Ticks  Fleas and Mites

questions.question:
Question 18: Which of the following is transmitted by the vector shown in the image given below? 645 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
651 
Sold by @itachibot The given image is of a cyclops or water flea. It is the vector for guinea worm disease or 
dracunculiasis and fish tapeworm infection. Humans are infected with these diseases by drinking water that contains cyclops. Its average life 
span is 3 months. Physical methods like straining and boiling of water can ensure the killing of this 
organism. Chemicals that can be used to control cyclops are chlorine, lime, and abate. Biological 
methods include Gambusia fish and barbel fish.
questions.chapter_heading: Medical Entomology - Ticks  Fleas and Mites

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following diseases is not associated with rodents?
questions.explanation:
Ascariasis is not associated with rodents. Diseases related to rodents are: â€¢ Bacterial - â€¢ Plague â€¢ Tularemia â€¢ Salmonellosis â€¢ Leptospirosis â€¢ Rat-bite fever â€¢ Viral - â€¢ Lassa fever â€¢ Encephalitis â€¢ Hemorrhagic fever â€¢ Rickettsial - â€¢ Scrub typhus â€¢ Endemic typhus â€¢ Rickettsial pox â€¢ Parasitic - â€¢ Hymenolepis diminuta â€¢ Leishmaniasis â€¢ Amoebiasis â€¢ Trichinosis â€¢ Chagas disease â€¢ Fungal - â€¢ Histoplasmosis â€¢ Ringworm 652 
Sold by @itachibot 653 
Sold by @itachibot Methods of Pest Control
questions.chapter_heading: Medical Entomology - Ticks  Fleas and Mites
